Another beautiful Orthodox Russian Church in Paris ‚ò¶Ô∏è‚ò¶Ô∏è‚ò¶Ô∏è

Pushing through an inconspicuous iron gate leads you into a narrow alley. Welcome to one of Paris's hidden treasures: the Russian Orthodox Church of St. Sergius of Radonezh.  The original German Lutheran church was confiscated during World War I and put up for sale by the French authorities. During the first wave of Russian emigration in 1917, the Alexander Nevsky Cathedral could not accommodate all the believers, and the working population of the 19th district did not feel comfortable in the bourgeois area. Therefore, the Orthodox community of Paris decides to purchase a new temple.  On July 18, 1924, on the day of memory of St. Sergius of Radonezh, the church, located a stone's throw from the Buttes-Chaumont park, was purchased at auction, and in March 1925 it was consecrated.  This is more than a church, it is an institution of Orthodox theology. The pearl of Russian Orthodox thought in the West, it trained hundreds of priests, bishops and theologians in the second half of the 20th century.  Sunday is ideal for visiting - the day of service.

Orthodox church built in 1861, not visible from the street and hidden at the end of an alley in the 19th arrondissement, rue de Crim√©e, an astonishing visit. Visit after 5 p.m.

This little-known Orthodox church, partially made of wood, all in color, is nestled on a promontory away from traffic, in the middle of the vegetation. When the Buttes-Chaumont is closed due to bad weather, it is good to take a walk in the small park that surrounds it. The church is not always open but if it is, don't hesitate to open the door. The parquet floor and the curtains give it a very special, warm atmosphere. Do not turn your back on the altar. Do not organize a picnic in the adjoining park even if there are benches. A monk would call you to order.

If you go up the slope from Crim√©e Street and push through the plants, you will see a church with this kind of atmosphere. It was originally a German Lutheran church, but it was confiscated by the French government during World War I, put up for sale, and then purchased in 1924, accepting new people as an Orthodox church. It is. It is famous for the beautiful wooden carvings on the front stairs and door.
